results.title: Limbering up
results.creator_credit: Frank Gardner and Central Office of Information
results.brief_description: Some of Britain’s outstanding young athletes seen at practice and in action. Sprinters David Jones and Jennie Smart, diver Brian Phelps and swimmer Anita Lonsborough, are among those who show their paces; analyses points of style and movement.

results.title: Lilydale: a change in pace
results.creator_credit: Barbara Boyd-Anderson and Victoria. Education Dept. Audio-Visual Resources Branch
results.brief_description: Presents two eras in the town of Lilydale in Victoria, the 1880’s and the 1980’s to form a case study of an Australian rural town as the metropolis advances towards it. It is a journey in time using archival photographs and diaries focusing particularly on the divergent life styles, attitudes and environments of the two eras of the district. Also includes a period recreation as a means to gain insights into those elements of Lilydale life. Suitable for secondary level.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Barbara Boyd-Anderson and Victoria. Education Dept. Audio-Visual Resources Branch

results.title: Lilya 4-ever = Lilya forever [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Lukas Moodysson, Lars Jonsson, Zentropa and Memfis
results.brief_description: Lukas Moodyson (Show me love, Together) delivers a bleak and melancholic story of a young Russian girl Lilya (Oksana Akinshina) who is abandoned by her mother (absconding to America with a boyfriend), deceived by her aunt and guardian and then betrayed by a friend who ruins Lilya’s reputation and consequently, her life. By a series of misunderstandings Lilya falls into prostitution and is then duped by an older man into believing a new life awaits her in the West. Once there however Lilya is forced into an array of humiliating and degrading circumstances that drive her to the brink. Set in the former Soviet Union, this is a somewhat desolate tale of dehumanisation, which contrasts starkly to the sunniness and humour of Moodyson’s “Together”, drawing on the grave themes of parent abandonment, child prostitution and human trafficking. Also available on VHS [318953].

results.title: Lily feeds a baby
results.creator_credit: Norman A. Uren and Western Australian Government Film Unit
results.brief_description: An Aboriginal mother who is unable to feed her infant herself is shown how to prepare baby’s bottle under camp life conditions. Water is boiled over an open fire, the bottle and the teat sterilised and the milk prepared from powdered milk.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Norman A. Uren and Western Australian Government Film Unit

results.title: Lily Aime Moi = Lily, Love Me
results.brief_description:
Francois, a journalist, is ordered to write an article on the life of a working class man. This is how he meets Claude who has just been abandoned by his wife, Lily. Francois decide to put his job on the side and attempts to help Claude mend his relationship with Lily. The film follows for three days the adventures of two men who were never meant to meet while brushing a warm and ironic portrait of friendships, complicity and relationships.

Credits: Producer, Michel Seydoux ; director, Maurice Dugowson ; writer, Michel Vianey ; photography, Andre Diot ; music, Edgardo Canton.
Cast: Rufus, Jean-Michel Folon, Patrick Dewaere, Zouzou, Roland Dubillard, Juliette Creco, Andreas Voutsinas, Tatiana Moukhine, Roger Blin, Miou-Miou, Henry Jaglom.

results.title: Lily
results.creator_credit: Julie Money, Women's Film Unit and Film Australia
results.brief_description: A dramatic discussion starter which confronts the social issue of racial prejudice shown through the eyes of a young Asian Australian woman, Lily. The film has the advantage of being both open-ended and humourous, allowing students to identify with the characters within the film and working as a stimulus to class discussion.
